text: <!channel> I've got a strange idea for the community... I get a few people reaching out every month, asking if I know any developers they could hire for various projects. I bet others here also are sent more projects than they have time for, and there are others who have less work than they want. Of course there are already online marketplaces for development... but we could start a #work or #jobs channel to post this stuff for people interested. Thoughts?

elements.text: I've got a strange idea for the community... I get a few people reaching out every month, asking if I know any developers they could hire for various projects. text: Ok, how about two jobs channels? The first is #odd-jobs and is what I initially proposed for random dev work. The other #jobs channel can be for projects somehow related to the future of coding. Or should we just have a single channel for all jobs? What about a distinction for part-time for full-time? (In other words, would you want to subscribe to only one of these specific channels or would you like to get all jobs in one channel?)

elements.text: Ok, how about two jobs channels? The first is #odd-jobs and is what I initially proposed for random dev work. (In other words, would you want to subscribe to only one of these specific channels or would you like to get all jobs in one channel?)

[February 6th, 2019 4:15 AM] fp: how about we start lots of Channels? One for each of the fine-grained themes that re-occur here? e.g.:
- better IDEs for techies
- declarative vs imperative
- state vs pure/monads
- spreadsheet derivatives
- history of programming

text:
I think one #jobs channel would be a great addition, but I don’t like seeing this Slack metastasize into many channels for specific topics. I get most out of this Slack by discovering stuff I wouldn’t have expected or actively searched for. Threads are a great way to compartmentalize specific discussions and ignore them if you’re not into it. 

I don’t want to be at a party, where I’m constantly told “Sorry, you can’t discuss that in the living room, that’s only appropriate in the kitchen. And please go upstairs to the second room on the right if you’re into that, or the basement if it’s about this other thing.” 
Isn’t the living room still big enough for all of us?

elements.text:
I think one #jobs channel would be a great addition, but I don’t like seeing this Slack metastasize into many channels for specific topics. I get most out of this Slack by discovering stuff I wouldn’t have expected or actively searched for. Threads are a great way to compartmentalize specific discussions and ignore them if you’re not into it. 

I don’t want to be at a party, where I’m constantly told “Sorry, you can’t discuss that in the living room, that’s only appropriate in the kitchen. And please go upstairs to the second room on the right if you’re into that, or the basement if it’s about this other thing.” 
Isn’t the living room still big enough for all of us?
